nodes.bodyText:
This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            Click a building in the scene layer to select it. Deselect buildings by tapping away from the buildings.
          
          
            
            Click a building in the scene layer to select it. Deselect buildings by clicking away from the buildings.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -1,25 +1,35 @@
-# Scene Layer Selection
+# Scene layer selection
 
-Select clicked features in a scene.
+Identify features in a scene to select.
 
-![](SceneLayerSelection.png)
+![Image of scene layer selection](SceneLayerSelection.png)
+
+## Use case
+
+You can select features to visually distinguish them with a selection color or highlighting. This can be useful to demonstrate the physical extent or associated attributes of a feature, or to initiate another action such as centering that feature in the scene view.
 
 ## How to use the sample
 
-Click on a building in the scene layer to select it. Unselect buildings by clicking away from the buildings.
+Click a building in the scene layer to select it. Deselect buildings by tapping away from the buildings.

nodes.bodyText:
reverting this back to original for Java platform ;)

  
    
  
    

  
  This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            2. Use `sceneView.setOnTouchListener(...)` to get the screen tap location `screenPoint`.
          
          
            
            2. Use `sceneView.setOnMouseClicked` to get the screen click location `Point2D`.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -1,25 +1,35 @@
-# Scene Layer Selection
+# Scene layer selection
 
-Select clicked features in a scene.
+Identify features in a scene to select.
 
-![](SceneLayerSelection.png)
+![Image of scene layer selection](SceneLayerSelection.png)
+
+## Use case
+
+You can select features to visually distinguish them with a selection color or highlighting. This can be useful to demonstrate the physical extent or associated attributes of a feature, or to initiate another action such as centering that feature in the scene view.
 
 ## How to use the sample
 
-Click on a building in the scene layer to select it. Unselect buildings by clicking away from the buildings.
+Click a building in the scene layer to select it. Deselect buildings by tapping away from the buildings.
 
 ## How it works
 
-To select geoelements in a scene layer:
-
 1. Create an `ArcGISSceneLayer` passing in the URL to a scene layer service.
-2. Use `sceneView.setOnMouseClicked` to get the screen click location `Point2D`.
-3. Call `sceneView.identifyLayersAsync(sceneLayer, point2D, tolerance, false, 1)` to identify features in the scene.
-4. From the resulting `IdentifyLayerResult`, get the list of identified `GeoElement`s with `result.getElements()`.
+2. Use `sceneView.setOnTouchListener(...)` to get the screen tap location `screenPoint`.

nodes.bodyText: Ohh I clearly lost focus on these ones! Sorry!!

-# Scene Layer Selection
+# Scene layer selection
 
-Select clicked features in a scene.
+Identify features in a scene to select.
 
-![](SceneLayerSelection.png)
+![Image of scene layer selection](SceneLayerSelection.png)
+
+## Use case
+
+You can select features to visually distinguish them with a selection color or highlighting. This can be useful to demonstrate the physical extent or associated attributes of a feature, or to initiate another action such as centering that feature in the scene view.
 
 ## How to use the sample
 
-Click on a building in the scene layer to select it. Unselect buildings by clicking away from the buildings.
+Click a building in the scene layer to select it. Deselect buildings by tapping away from the buildings.
 
 ## How it works
 
-To select geoelements in a scene layer:
-
 1. Create an `ArcGISSceneLayer` passing in the URL to a scene layer service.
-2. Use `sceneView.setOnMouseClicked` to get the screen click location `Point2D`.
-3. Call `sceneView.identifyLayersAsync(sceneLayer, point2D, tolerance, false, 1)` to identify features in the scene.
-4. From the resulting `IdentifyLayerResult`, get the list of identified `GeoElement`s with `result.getElements()`.
+2. Use `sceneView.setOnTouchListener(...)` to get the screen tap location `screenPoint`.
+3. Call `sceneView.identifyLayersAsync(sceneLayer, screenPoint, tolerance, false, 1)` to identify features in the scene.

@@ -1,25 +1,35 @@
-# Scene Layer Selection
+# Scene layer selection
 
-Select clicked features in a scene.
+Identify features in a scene to select.
 
-![](SceneLayerSelection.png)
+![Image of scene layer selection](SceneLayerSelection.png)
+
+## Use case
+
+You can select features to visually distinguish them with a selection color or highlighting. This can be useful to demonstrate the physical extent or associated attributes of a feature, or to initiate another action such as centering that feature in the scene view.
 
 ## How to use the sample
 
-Click on a building in the scene layer to select it. Unselect buildings by clicking away from the buildings.
+Click a building in the scene layer to select it. Deselect buildings by tapping away from the buildings.
 
 ## How it works
 
-To select geoelements in a scene layer:
-
 1. Create an `ArcGISSceneLayer` passing in the URL to a scene layer service.
-2. Use `sceneView.setOnMouseClicked` to get the screen click location `Point2D`.
-3. Call `sceneView.identifyLayersAsync(sceneLayer, point2D, tolerance, false, 1)` to identify features in the scene.
-4. From the resulting `IdentifyLayerResult`, get the list of identified `GeoElement`s with `result.getElements()`.
+2. Use `sceneView.setOnTouchListener(...)` to get the screen tap location `screenPoint`.
+3. Call `sceneView.identifyLayersAsync(sceneLayer, screenPoint, tolerance, false, 1)` to identify features in the scene.
+4. From the resulting `IdentifyLayerResult`, get the list of identified `GeoElements` with `result.getElements()`.
